title: Grades 6-8: American Sign Language, Level I
subject: Languages Other Than English (2014-)

document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Languages Other Than English

0838ED90D7334B41AEF25415605C8E59.description: show evidence of becoming a lifelong learner by using ASL at the novice proficiency level for personal enrichment and/or career development.

EE17001A757548028934B01AA239BA29.description: be aware of methods of technology to communicate with the Deaf/ASL community; and

5FA4F70D7C5A4EE1B2E6362B606172B8.description: apply ASL at the novice proficiency level in or out of the school setting through involvement in cultural activities such as attending Deaf events;

8347753F1A9549C39D4C1275F2C8413D.description: Communities. The student participates in the Deaf/ASL community by using ASL. The student is expected to:

86EB6545E7B84D928C88814D59A672A4.description: demonstrate an understanding of how one language and culture can influence another.

12A756B220134AFA9953ED25E6B1651B.description: demonstrate an understanding of the nature of culture through comparisons of the student's own culture and the American Deaf culture; and

70302ADCC8694F12BD9D242E587AB655.description: demonstrate an understanding of the nature of language through comparisons of the student's own language and ASL;

FFD3BBF28B8F42CCA533271759CF603A.description: Comparisons. The student develops insight into the nature of language and culture by comparing the student's own language and culture to ASL and American Deaf culture. The student is expected to:

E2069D7B89744C8F894AED69120E6C23.description: use ASL to obtain, reinforce, or expand knowledge of other subject areas.

E9AFE00C5EEB46629A70131205F019D8.description: use resources and digital technology to gain access to information about ASL and Deaf culture; and

4C5B5C8DF54348B3ABDBE20034D622DB.description: Connections. The student uses ASL to make connections with other subject areas and to acquire information. The student is expected to:

EA33ECECD8884410A64E764F40F033CD.description: demonstrate an understanding of Deaf history and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture.

8F0D22920BEA4C5091C5EE3D9471C6A9.description: show evidence of appreciation of the contributions by the Deaf and how they are applied to the perspectives of American Deaf culture such as historical, geographical, political, artistic, and scientific avenues; and

A835D2BD3FF54CCB9945086401C3C806.description: show evidence of appreciation of ASL literature created by the Deaf and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

B5446D4A5C484F7CA1917419C16AA9D5.description: recognize and use Deaf cultural norms to demonstrate an understanding of the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

46491697642649BABFDF570816D50742.description: Cultures. The student gains knowledge and understanding of American Deaf culture. The student is expected to:

86AE75F9743F4EB7A19A5C982FDC7C5A.description: be exposed to and experience ASL literature such as handshape stories that follows traditional cultural features.

A7477EA50EFE4DF08C837535642D7BEF.description: demonstrate appropriate usage of ASL phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics; and

BD3FE13CEF9B4E55800CE6719765D0F0.description: convey information in ASL using familiar words, concepts, classifiers, phrases, and sentences to others without voice;

75507382113A4EB29EEB00D06C536C92.description: demonstrate an understanding of basic ASL such as simple stories, everyday commands, and brief instructions when dealing with familiar topics;

19E649FFCDB0458B9190CF0FDDB9C7C7.description: engage in a variety of ASL exchanges of learned material to socialize and to provide and obtain information;

E37E6C11597D4273A9AEA328F39B8512.description: Communication. The student communicates in ASL using expressive and receptive communication skills without voice. The student is expected to:
